message: Today the new Congress was sworn into office and is ready to “hit the ground running.”  I am excited about the opportunities that it and the new Administration will have to do good things for the country once the new President is inaugurated on January 20.   First on the agenda will be regulations.  The last years of the Obama Administration saw a blizzard of regulations that killed jobs and added burdens to every sized business.  Congress will act to repeal or correct some of the most burdensome regulations, and we will push legislation that requires all major regulations, defined as having more than a $100 million effect on the economy, to be approved by Congress before they can be implemented.   Second is Obamacare.  Portions of Obamacare can be repealed with a majority vote in the Senate rather than the 60 votes often required.  House Republicans issued specific health care reform proposals last spring as part of our “A Better Way” plan.  These proposals will serve as the starting point for the new approach to health care.  Working with the new Administration, which has a lot of discretion on the details of Obamacare, we will repeal the failing scheme and transition to a commonsense health care plan that will serve patients, providers, and the country as a whole much better.     You can read more of this newsletter at my website here: http://thornberry.house.gov/news/email/show.aspx?ID=HTCIKS5UUYOF7OYEYJFDSF2Q5U

Today, I introduced my first bill of the 115th Congress - the “Death Tax Repeal Act.” This simple, two-page bill would permanently and fully eliminate the death tax, which undermines one of America’s most important means of capital formation: building a family enterprise. Death should never be a taxable event. All Americans should be able to work hard, build, and save knowing that they can pass on what they have earned to their children and grandchildren.

Tonight, I voted for and the House passed H.Res 11, which expresses the House’s disapproval of the U.N.’s latest action against Israel.   For the first time in 36 years, the United States failed to veto a U.N. Resolution condemning Israeli settlements as illegal. It was a final jab against Israel, and the result will be to undermine the Israeli and Palestinian peace process and contribute to politically motivated attacks against Israel. The new Administration will have to repair this important relationship.

Last night, I voted for and the House passed the REINS Act of 2017, which will require any executive branch rule or regulation with an annual economic impact of $100 million or more — designated by the Office of Management and Budget as a “major rule”— to come before Congress for an up-or-down vote before being enacted.  Congressional Republicans will have a good opportunity to work with the incoming Administration to roll back the blizzard of regulations that has come out of Washington over the past eight years. The REINS Act is the first of several planned bills that will make the regulatory process more transparent and accountable and repeal or correct some of the most harmful regulations.

The 115th Congress was sworn in last week, and we have “hit the ground running.” There are several key issues Congressional Republicans will be working with the new Administration to address. I invite you to learn more by watching my brief video message about our agenda.    Please let me know what you think in the comments section below.

Today, Senator Cornyn and I introduced legislation in the U.S. House and Senate to protect landowners' rights along the Red River from federal ownership claims. Private property owners should never have to worry about the federal government coming in and taking away their land, especially land that has never been properly surveyed. Our bills will help provide these property owners the certainty that they deserve to know where public lands end and private lands begin.  The legislation will provide legal certainty to property owners along the Red River by:  • Commissioning a survey of the majority of the 116-mile stretch of contested area along the Red River using the gradient boundary survey method developed and backed by the Supreme Court to find the proper ownership boundary between public and private land.    • Ordering that the survey be conducted by licensed and qualified surveyors chosen by Texas and Oklahoma.  • Providing states the authority to oversee the surveyors and approve the final survey to ensure the Supreme Court instructions are properly followed.  • Requiring that a notice of survey approval, a copy of the survey, and any related field notes be provided to each individual land owner after the survey is completed.  • Ensuring that nothing in the bill alters the Red River Boundary Compact, modifies the interests of the states, or harms the rights of the impacted federally recognized Indian Tribes.

This week, the House and Senate passed budget resolutions that are the critical first steps to repealing and replacing Obamacare. This effort is at the top of our agenda, and we intend to make sure that it is done right. Americans deserve health care that is affordable, patient focused, and that saves the benefits that they have paid into.
"Darkness cannot drive out darkness; only light can do that. Hate cannot drive out hate; only love can do that." - Martin Luther King, Jr.

Inmate Manning was convicted of multiple acts of espionage against the United States and other serious military misconduct. These actions potentially put our country and fellow soldiers at serious risk. The President’s commutation of Manning's sentence sends a terrible message to the world that the penalties for damaging our security can be swayed by politics.

The peaceful transition of power is one of the hallmarks of American democracy. It may seem normal to us today, but as President Reagan said in 1981, it is "nothing short of a miracle." I always consider it an honor to witness it in person.   I am looking forward to all of the good things Congress can accomplish by working with our new President and his team.
I will be interviewed live on Fox News at roughly 9:10 am Texas time to discuss how we can rebuild the military to make all Americans safer. Tune in if you can.

I want to share with you an article I wrote for Fox News about the opportunity we have to rebuild our military.   To protect America’s security, we are going to have to pull America’s military out of the swamp of Washington politics. Making America great again begins with making our military great again. As President Trump begins this daunting task, many of us in Congress will be his strongest allies.  You can read the full article by clicking the image below.

Scam artists who use fake area codes, text messages, and emails to steal from innocent people have been on the rise in recent years. Last night, I voted for and the House passed a bill, H.R. 423, that would expand the Federal Communications Commission’s authority to enforce criminal penalties and fine individuals that use fake information about a caller’s identification to defraud or harm another person.   In one of the most recent widespread scams, criminals call or send emails to the victims and identify themselves as Department of the Treasury or Internal Revenue Service (IRS) officials. They claim that the victim owes money to the IRS and that they must pay the balance immediately using a credit card, pre-paid debit card, or wire transfer. They threaten punishment, including arrest or suspension of a business or driver’s license if the debt is not paid immediately. The scammers may also use fake badge numbers and use phone numbers with a 202 Washington area code.   If someone unexpectedly calls claiming to be from the IRS or the Treasury Department, and uses the threat of legal action if you do not pay immediately, that is a sign that it is not the IRS calling and your cue to hang up. If you believe you have been a target of this type of scam, report it to the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration at https://www.treasury.gov/tigta/contact_report_scam.shtml or 1-800-366-4484.   Reporting these incidents helps in the following ways according to the Department of the Treasury:    • Providing the call-back number can lead to arrests. • It builds an evidentiary trail. • Telephone numbers are shut down. • Scam attempts are cataloged.

Yesterday, President Trump signed executive memorandums that expedite the authorization of permits for the Dakota Access Pipeline and invite TransCanada to resubmit its application to build the Keystone XL Pipeline. The construction of these pipelines could create thousands of jobs and help us gain greater energy security.

It was an honor to receive the U.S. Army Decoration for Distinguished Civilian Service from Army Chief of Staff Gen. Milley yesterday. The real credit belongs to the dedicated military service members and their families who sacrifice so much to provide for our nation’s defense. I will continue to do everything I can to support the exceptional men and women serving in our Armed Forces and see that they have the resources they need to carry out their mission.

Congress continues to push back the blizzard of regulations that came out of the Obama Administration. Last week, two bills to eliminate regulations that harm the energy industry were sent to the President’s desk, and he is expected to sign them. You can read more about those rules in the article below.

Yesterday, I spoke with Wolf Blitzer about the need to rebuild our military to help ensure that our troops on the front lines have the resources and equipment necessary to fulfill their mission. You can watch the interview below.

This week the House passed two resolutions that repeal Obama-era attempts to regulate our schools from Washington. Local control of schools is very important, and when the Senate passes these bills, local communities will have more say over their local schools. You can read more about those two rules in the article below.

This evening, the House passed an important bill for our part of Texas and private landowners everywhere. The bill known as the “Red River Gradient Boundary Survey Act,” H.R. 428, which I introduced earlier this year, passed by a vote of 250-171.   This bill essentially requires the BLM to do what it should have done all along by establishing a fair and balanced process to conduct an accurate survey of contested land along the Red River to find the proper boundary between public and private ownership. Private property owners should never have to worry about the federal government coming in and taking away their land, especially land that has never been properly surveyed.   I will continue working with the landowners, local and state officials, and Senator Cornyn (R-TX) until this issue is resolved once and for all. You can watch my floor speech about the importance of this bill by clicking the picture below.

President Trump’s and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s meeting today is a good sign that the new Administration is ready to repair our relationship with Israel. They are one of our most important allies. Both of our countries face increasing threats around the world, making it that much more important to stand together.

The House voted to overturn five Obama-era regulations this week. One was a regulation that banned states from denying certain funds that would go to health service providers that provide abortions. Another was a regulation that stopped the states from requiring a drug test for unemployment benefits. You can read about the first regulation in the article below.

Yesterday, I was honored to present the Congressional Medal to Talon Lewis, a sophomore at Tascosa High School in Amarillo.  Talon worked diligently to meet the goals set out by the award in service, personal development, physical fitness, and expedition.  It gives me great hope to meet future leaders who are committed to serving others such as Talon.

Last week, I met with business owners in Amarillo, Wichita Falls, Montague County, and Gainesville to get their input on which regulations hurt their ability to grow and create jobs. Putting common sense back into federal regulation will continue to be a high priority.

One of the best parts of this job is getting to know many of the people in our area who serve others. Last week as I met with Amarillo Downtown Kiwanis, a Congressional Award winner, and as Sally and I toured the new Heal the City building full of volunteers, I was again reminded of all those who do not just sit and complain but roll up their sleeves to do something directly that helps a neighbor.  They are the real strength of this country.
I appreciated Wise Co. Judge J.D. Clark visiting with me yesterday in my Washington office. He was also my guest last night at President Trump’s address to the Joint Session of Congress.”

I thought the President’s speech last night was the most positive and goal oriented that I have heard him give. He talked about a future where children do not have to worry about violence, where they have educational opportunities, and where our country is safer. Those are things we should all aspire to and work together to achieve.

EPA Administrator Pruitt’s decision to withdraw the methane emissions ICR for the oil and natural gas industry is a welcome move away from the previous Administration’s agenda to expand their authority and control over many parts of our society. We have a responsibility to be good stewards of our environment, but that does not mean that the federal government should be burdening our nation’s energy producers with needless and costly regulations like this one.  There is no question that these burdensome regulations like the ICR drive up costs for businesses and consumers alike. By the EPA’s own estimate, the ICR would have cost producers $42 million to comply during a time when the industry is already dealing with financial hardships.

Sally and I are praying for all those who are being affected by the wildfires throughout the Panhandle and the first responders working to protect us.   It is important to pay attention to and heed evacuation orders in your area.

Sally and I continue to pray for those who have lost so much in recent days, especially the families and friends of Sloan Everett, Cody Crockett, Sydney Wallace, and Cade Koch. Nothing can ever replace the loss of a loved one.   For those who have lost livestock and property, it is important to assess the losses as soon as it is safe and begin the assistance process with the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA).  Agriculture producers who have suffered livestock and property losses in the recent wildfires to file a Notice of Loss with the USDA to begin the federal assistance process. A Notice of Loss must be filed within 30 days of the time of the loss by phone or in person at local USDA county service centers. To learn more, visit my website here: http://thornberry.house.gov/district/panhandle-wildfires.htm

Obamacare is failing and is damaging the health care of all Americans. Since first being implemented, it has driven up insurance premiums, hurt small businesses, and lowered the quality of and access to care.  Last week, House Republicans put forth an initial proposal to repeal and replace this disastrous law. It is the first step in a process that will lead to patient-centered care that provides more choices and lowers prices instead of creating more mandates and taxes.  There are opportunities to improve the plan during the legislative process, but it is important to get started and get this job done. The procedure rules – especially in the Senate – mean that Obamacare cannot be repealed and replaced in a single bill.  The tax and spending portions of Obamacare can be repealed and replaced under a special procedure known as reconciliation that only requires 51 votes in the Senate rather than the 60 required for most bills. Other parts of the repeal and replace will need 60 votes. There are currently 52 Republican seats in the Senate. In addition, the new Administration also has the ability to change many of the regulations associated with Obamacare.  There is already disinformation being circulated by outside organizations seeking to fundraise and garner attention for themselves. You can read about some of the most important provisions of the proposal on my website at http://thornberry.house.gov/healthcare.

Health care under Obamacare is in trouble. This year individual premiums are up an average of 25 percent. More than one-third of the counties in the country have only one company offering insurance. Many of the policies have deductibles over $5,000, making them unusable for some families. Without action, it will crash. You can read more about the step-by-step approach we are taking here: https://housegop.leadpages.co/healthcare/#step-by-step

The House will vote to repeal and replace Obamacare with the American Health Care Act (ACHA). It will repeal the taxes on prescriptions and medical devices that are helping drive up costs for everyone. And it ends the one-size-fits-all approach that also drives up costs and limits options for patients. You can read more about it here: http://thornberry.house.gov/healthcare

The American Health Care Act will not touch Medicare benefits in any way.  There are misleading ads that try to scare people.  But the fact is Medicare benefits are not reduced.  You can read the bill here: www.readthebill.gop

I was very disappointed that the bill to repeal and replace Obamacare did not pass the House on Friday. I expect that we will see even higher premiums, fewer providers, and lower quality of care as the problems with Obamacare continue to grow.

My office is now taking submissions for the 2017 Congressional Art Competition. The annual competition, which has selected winners from each of the U.S. Congressional Districts and Territories since 1982, is open to any high school student in the 13th District of Texas.  The winning artwork will be displayed for the entire year in the United States Capitol. In addition, the winning student will be invited to participate in the exhibition’s opening celebration in Washington, D.C. this summer. You can learn more about it on my website: http://thornberry.house.gov/art/

The FCC is alerting people about a new phone scam. You can read more about the scam from ABC News:    “The scam begins as soon as a person answers the phone. A recorded voice or an actual person asks: ‘Can you hear me?’ And the consumer responds, ‘Yes.’”   “‘The caller then records the consumer's 'Yes' response and thus obtains a voice signature. This signature can later be used by the scammers to pretend to be the consumer and authorize fraudulent charges via telephone,’ an FCC news release said.”   “The FCC advised consumers to immediately hang up if they receive this type of call. It also said that if consumers had responded ‘Yes’ to a similar call in the past, they should keep an eye on all financial statements for any unauthorized charges.”   The FCC also shared the following tips:   1. Don't answer calls from unknown numbers. Let them go to voicemail.   2. If you answer and the caller (often a recording) asks you to hit a button to stop receiving calls, just hang up. Scammers often use these tricks to identify, and then target, live respondents.   3. If you receive a scam call, write down the number and file a complaint with the FCC so we can help identify and take appropriate action to help consumers targeted by illegal callers.   4. Ask your phone service provider if it offers a robocall blocking service. If not, encourage your provider to offer one. You can also visit the FCC's website for information and resources on available robocall blocking tools to help reduce unwanted calls. Consider registering all of your telephone numbers in the National Do Not Call Registry.   http://abcnews.go.com/Business/fcc-warns-consumers-phone-scam/story?id=46405703

I had a great meeting in Washington this week with Texas Farm Bureau members from across our area. Among other topics, we discussed Republican efforts to eliminate regulations that harm agriculture producers, tax reform, and the importance of international trade to farmers and ranchers.    We also discussed private property rights, and I provided an update on the effort to protect landowners along the Red River from a federal land grab by the BLM. You can read more about our meeting in the article below.   http://texasfarmbureau.org/thornberry-provides-update-red-river-legislation/

The Bureau of Land Management’s (BLM) announced that it used incorrect methodology in three surveys that are the basis for the federal government’s claims to private property along the Red River.  Their admission and the decision to suspend the surveys is welcome news.  The portions of the river that the agency has surveyed strayed widely from the accepted gradient boundary survey method established by the Supreme Court in Oklahoma v. Texas. It is encouraging that the BLM has admitted their error and that all administrative action will be suspended until the matter is resolved. I will continue working with the landowners, local and state officials, and Senator John Cornyn until this issue is resolved once and for all.

Yesterday, House Armed Services Committee held a hearing with the Service Chiefs of all branches of the military to hear their assessments of the consequences of the failure to pass the 2017 Department of Defense Appropriations bill with supplemental funding.   The House passed the bill on March 8 by a vote of 371 to 48, but the Senate has not yet acted on it. As the Senate considers adopting the 2017 appropriations bill - or imposing billions in cuts that a Continuing Resolution (CR) would represent - I requested an assessment of the harm a full-year CR or failure to include the added funding requested by the President would do to our men and women in uniform.   According to the Department of Defense the military would face the following consequences:  • Expected pay will be cut for service members, including promised bonuses.  • The Marine Corps will reduce its force size by more than 2,000 Marines.   • The Navy will halt the recruitment of 1,000 sailors.    • The Air Force will halt the recruitment of 2,000 airmen.  • The Air Force will be unable to retain pilots when it is already 1,500 pilots short.  • Only one deploying Army unit will be able to conduct critical training after July 15.  • Navy training cuts will result in 20-30 percent fewer qualified pilots than required.  • The Air Force may have to ground all non-deploying squadrons on May 1.  • The Navy will ground four of the nine non-deployed carrier air wings.  • Three ships will not be deployed, creating gaps in Europe and the Middle East.  • The Marine Corps will cease flight operations in the United States in July.  • Only one third of all Navy Aircraft will be fully mission capable.  • The Navy will cancel or delay critical repairs on 14 ships.   You can watch my opening statement below.

I am scheduled to speak with Chris Wallace tomorrow morning on Fox News Sunday around 8:15 Texas time to discuss North Korea, recent strikes in Syria and Afghanistan, and other national defense issues. Tune in if you can.
Sally and I wish you a happy and blessed Easter. Please keep all those who are serving our nation and their families in your prayers.

I enjoyed visiting with the employees of Amarillo Gear and hearing more about the good work they do. They are the leading manufacturer worldwide of right angle gears for use in irrigation, industrial, and firefighting pumps. I am always reminded of the strong work ethic of the people in our local community and what it means to the economy.

I was honored to receive the "Legislative Excellence Award" presented by the National Association of Manufacturers during my recent visit to Sealed Air Corporation in Iowa Park. This is not my first visit to Sealed Air, but I continue to be impressed by their innovative products and strong workforce.

I enjoyed visiting with business and community leaders in Bridgeport last week. We had an interesting and productive discussion focusing on regulations, employment of veterans, and other ways the federal government impacts businesses and the local community. We have made some progress on reducing regulations, but there is much work still to do.

Last week, I traveled to Europe with House Speaker Paul Ryan and several other Members of Congress to visit our troops stationed overseas and to meet with our allies in the region. The purpose of the trip was to discuss the important national security challenges facing us all and to reaffirm our strong commitment to our NATO partners. We met with leaders in Norway, the United Kingdom, Poland, and Estonia.

President Trump issued an executive order this week to create an interagency task force to identify legislative, regulatory, and policy changes to promote agriculture, economic development, job growth, infrastructure improvements, technological innovation, energy security, and quality of life in rural America.  This task force has the potential to do a lot of good for our part of Texas and for agriculture producers across America. I commend President Trump for creating it. For too long, farmers and ranchers in rural America have suffered due to harmful regulations and policies coming out of Washington. This is an opportunity to identify the areas where we can make positive changes that will help support our agriculture producers.  The President’s order coincides with Congress’s ongoing effort to repeal or roll back regulations that were issued under the previous administration. Since February, we have passed and the President has signed 13 bills to nullify specific regulations that they identified as unnecessary over burdensome.  I also want congratulated former Governor Sonny Perdue (R-GA) on his confirmation and swearing in as Secretary of Agriculture.   I am pleased that the Senate confirmed Secretary Perdue’s nomination by an overwhelming bipartisan majority. Now that he is sworn in, he can begin to tackle many of the important issues that face our agriculture producers.

The tax reform outline that was released this week by the White House is another encouraging step toward fixing our broken tax code. The proposal would simplify both individual and business taxes with the goal of encouraging economic growth.  Among other provisions, the proposal would:  • Eliminate the Estate Tax, commonly referred to as the “Death Tax”; • Reduce the number of tax brackets from seven to three; • Repeal the 3.8 percent Obamacare tax on investment income; and • Reduce the corporate tax rate to 15 percent.   Small business owners, farmers, and ranchers are particularly vulnerable to the Death Tax, making it more difficult for future generations to build upon their family’s hard work. Death should never be a taxable event. All Americans should be able to work hard, build, and save knowing that they can pass on what they have earned to their children and grandchildren.
I was on Fox News yesterday to talk about North Korea, defense spending and rebuilding the military. You can watch the full interview below.

A Caprock High School student has been selected to represent the 13th Congressional District of Texas in the nationwide 2017 Congressional Art Competition. A drawing submitted by Haley Garber, daughter of Kevin and Suzanne Garber of Amarillo, will be displayed in the hallways of the United States Capitol for an entire year.   We had many impressive pieces of art submitted by students from across our part of Texas for this year’s Congressional Art Competition. Haley’s drawing demonstrates a great deal of artistic talent. I am proud to have it represent our district in the Capitol building for the next year.

Today, I voted for and the House passed the “American Health Care Act” (AHCA) which repeals and replaces much of the “Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act,” also known as Obamacare. I also voted for another bill, H.R. 2192, that ensures that provisions in the AHCA apply to Members of Congress and congressional staff.  In order to pass the Senate, this bill was considered under a special procedure that directly affects spending and revenue. Additional legislation will repeal and replace other portions of Obamacare and the new Administration will change many of the regulations associated with Obamacare.  The bill that the House passed does not reduce or change in any way current Medicare benefits. The bill will increase Medicare payments to hospitals that serve a higher than average percentage of uninsured patients. However, health coverage benefits to Medicare beneficiaries are not altered.  The bill repeals the Obamacare taxes, subsidies, and mandates. This includes the individual and employer mandates, the additional 0.9 percent Medicare payroll tax on high-income earners, along with the taxes imposed on medical devices, health insurers, and prescription drugs, among others. It also places a one-year moratorium on government funding for Planned Parenthood.  I believe that Obamacare has caused enormous problems for the American health care system. It is important that it be replaced with an approach that puts more decisions in the hands of patients and their health care professionals. The AHCA is a big step in this direction.

Today is National Military Spouse Appreciation Day, and we join many others in expressing gratitude to an amazing group of people. Military spouses serve our nation every day, often at great personal sacrifice.  They play an integral part in the character and morale of our military, and we honor them on this day and always.

This agreement could have a positive impact on our part of Texas depending on the final details of the deal. Good trade agreements can help create jobs here at home and enhance our nation’s security. Trade is very important to our part of Texas, especially for our agriculture producers.
With gratitude to all Mothers, past and present, Happy Mother's Day!

Today is Armed Forces Day. Please join Sally and me in honoring the brave men and women of all five military branches. Without their service and sacrifice, we would not have the freedoms and security that we enjoy every day.

Our hearts go out to the families of the victims and to those hurt in the bombing in Manchester.  It reminds us, yet again, that there are terrorists plotting and planning every day to kill innocent people — in this case, many children.  As Memorial Day approaches, it is also a good time to remember those who have died in the last 16 years of fighting to stop the terrorists from carrying out their attacks and to protect our citizens. That fight obviously continues.

Today, the House passed the PRIVATE Act to protect troops from nonconsensual sharing of intimate images by other military members. I continue to be disturbed by deplorable acts that degrade our service members.  I am encouraged, however, that the House took swift and significant action to begin addressing the issue by strengthening the UCMJ to ensure that personnel are protected and that perpetrators are held appropriately accountable.  I credit Rep. McSally’s strong leadership in bringing Members together and in getting action quickly on this measure.

The House passed the “Reducing Regulatory Burdens Act of 2017,” H.R. 953, today. This bill will relieve farmers and ranchers of having to obtain duplicative and unnecessary permits for pesticide. This is another step in our effort to push back the blizzard of regulations that come out of Washington.

Two important reports came out yesterday on health care. The first shows that under Obamacare the average premium cost has more than doubled. Texas is a little better than average - our premiums have increased 82%. The second, by the Congressional Budget Office, confirms that the House health care bill will lower premiums and will save the taxpayers about $119 billion over ten years. It also says that more people would be without insurance than under Obamacare. Of course, it is not surprising that if the federal government does not make people buy health insurance, fewer  of them will.  You can read the Health and Human Services report here: https://www.hhs.gov/about/news/2017/05/23/hhs-report-average-health-insurance-premiums-doubled-2013.html  You can read the Congressional Budget Office report here: https://www.cbo.gov/publication/52752

Dear Friends,  On the final Monday in May, we should all take a moment to reflect on the importance of Memorial Day and its true purpose: To honor the military servicemembers who made the ultimate sacrifice for our country and the families they left behind. It is also a day to be thankful for the freedoms that they and so many others have fought to protect. I encourage everyone to take the time to honor the brave men and women who were called to battle and in doing so lost their lives.   Traditionally, Memorial Day is observed by decorating the graves of fallen servicemembers and that is certainly appropriate. While the sacrifices they made can never truly be repaid, an even greater tribute is to live our lives in a way that honors them and their sacrifice.   It is also important that we remember the loved ones who were left behind and their sacrifice to our country. Those mothers, fathers, spouses, and children bear a burden that few of us can understand.  President Bush gave a speech to commemorate Memorial Day at the beaches of Normandy in 2002. He spoke about the families of our fallen warfighters by saying in part:  “Behind every grave of a fallen soldier is a story of the grief that came to a wife, a mother, a child, a family or a town. A World War II orphan has described her family's life after her father was killed on the field in Germany. ‘My mother,’ she said, ‘had lost everything she was waiting for. She lost her dreams.’  “Each person buried here understood his duty but also dreamed of going back home to the people and the things he knew. Each had plans and hopes of his own that parted with him forever when he died.”  Of course, our gratitude must extend beyond one day a year. Among other ways, ensuring that the government's commitments made to those who served and to their families are kept is important. And Congress keeps working to improve the care and service our veterans receive.   Sally and I are grateful for all who serve or have served, and we hope you join us in remembering and honoring those who made the ultimate sacrifice.
NA

I recently had the opportunity to visit with the Pampa Lions Club to talk about the House-passed healthcare bill, funding our military, and other topics.  There is much more to be done as we push for commonsense solutions that address the issues facing folks in our area.
NA

Recently, I traveled to South Korea to meet with our military leaders, consult with government officials, and to demonstrate our commitment to this strong alliance. The U.S.-South Korea alliance is as critical today as it ever has been. We appreciate the sustained and significant investment South Korea makes in defense. They provide a strong example for other nations to follow.

Our thoughts and prayers go out to the people of London and the victims of the recent attack. Once again, we must acknowledge the work that must still be done in order to stop this unthinkable evil and remember those who have fought, and are still fighting, to stop terrorists from carrying out their attacks on innocent people.

73 years ago today, American, Canadian, and British troops landed on the 50-mile stretch of the Normandy beaches held by Nazi Germany. The invasion began at dawn and by days’ end, more than 156,000 Allied troops stood on those beaches and began the long and arduous fight to free Europe from Hitler’s grasp. Thousands of men would never leave the beach or see their homes again.     Today is a day to remember the men and women who risked everything to rid the world of this tyranny.  It is also a day to remember the importance of our allies who stood shoulder to shoulder with us to advance freedom and liberty across the world.

Today, the House passed H.R. 2213, the “Anti-Border Corruption Reauthorization Act of 2017.” This bill will allow the Commissioner of the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) to waive the polygraph requirement for candidates who have already been vetted and have served as either a law enforcement officer or a member of the Armed Services and have a security clearance.   The CBP has struggled to recruit and hire additional agents because of the pre-employment polygraph requirement, and as a result, is understaffed.  Our immigration laws are in need of a major overhaul, and we must start with border security and interior enforcement. This bill is a good step in making sure that our families are safe and that trade and commerce can be conducted with legitimacy.
I was on Fox News this morning to talk about the defense budget and the impact it has on the fight against ISIS. You can watch the full interview below.

Yesterday, the House Armed Services Committee held a hearing with Defense Secretary Mattis and Joint Chiefs Chairman General Dunford to discuss the Administration’s Fiscal Year 2018 National Defense Budget Request.   I am encouraged that the President has committed to rebuilding the military, but the Administration’s budget request falls short of this goal. We have to make sure that the men and women who fight for our freedom are provided with everything they need to be successful. It is also our responsibility to make sure that the budget provides the security we need to protect our nation. Our country faces more serious and complex security challenges than ever before, and we must make sure that we are prepared to deter aggression and maintain peace.   You can watch the full hearing below.

My thoughts and prayers are with those that were wounded in this morning’s horrible attack. Sally, my staff, and I are all safe. Today is a day to thank police officers around the country and hug their loved ones for the sacrifices they make to keep us safe every day. Without the Capitol police officers’ bravery this morning the results may have been different. They are heroes.

I enjoyed visiting with seventeen young people from our area who came to D.C. as part of the 2017 Youth Tour with Texas Electric Cooperatives. These students earned a trip to our nation’s capital by winning either a speech or essay contest sponsored by their local electric cooperatives. Our future looks bright with these outstanding students in leadership roles.

The decision by the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Secretary Sonny Perdue to extend emergency grazing on CRP lands will allow ranchers who were affected by the Panhandle wildfires much needed time to rebuild fencing, replant grass, and provide a safe home for their livestock. I appreciate the Secretary listening to our concerns and providing agriculture producers in the Panhandle with more time to get back on their feet.  You can read the letter from the USDA here:
Getting ready to speak with Maria Bartiromo for Fox Sunday Morning Futures about Afghanistan and the defense bill we are about to consider.
I spoke with Fox News yesterday about a variety of national security topics, including the defense policy bill, which the Armed Services Committee will take up this week and next.

Yesterday, I was glad to meet with Glenn Barham, President of Sheppard Military Affairs Committee, Darron Leiker, City Manager of Wichita Falls, and others attending the Association of Defense Communities meeting in Washington.  We discussed the vital support that local communities provide to military installations across the country and the need for a defense budget that meets the threats we face around the world.

This afternoon, the House observed a moment of silence in honor of the service members who lost their lives on the U.S.S. Fitzgerald last week. A full investigation of this incident is essential, but as it is being conducted we all should continue to pray for those affected by this tragedy.

Several years ago, Congress passed sweeping welfare reforms to help able-bodied recipients get back on their feet and return to the workforce. Today, I voted for and the House passed H.R. 2842, the “Accelerating Individuals into the Workforce Act,” to help further that goal. This bill will encourage employer-led partnerships to help people move from welfare to work by providing recipients with work experience.

Today marks the 67th anniversary of the start of the Korean War. We continue to face turbulence there with an unstable leader and growing military threat. This anniversary is yet another reminder that we must be strong and stand with our allies.
I recently visited with Tony St. James from “All Ag, All Day” to talk about national defense, trade, and agriculture. You can listen to the full interview here:

I welcome the news that the EPA is withdrawing the Obama Administration’s Waters of the United States (WOTUS) Rule that is disastrous for rural communities and agricultural producers.  Earlier this Congress, I introduced H.R. 1261, the “Federal Regulatory Certainty for Water Act,” to clarify what “navigable waters” means and especially what it does not.  Placing a good definition in law will help ensure that the courts and future administrations will not revive attempts to regulate every bar ditch and buffalo wallow across the country.
NA
NA

Happy Fourth of July!  None of us should ever lose sight of what a remarkable country this is -- in large part because of principles which guided our founding and because of the colonists’ willingness to fight for their freedom.  We still must be willing to defend our freedoms.  It is a great honor for me to serve as Chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, but it is also a significant responsibility.  Men and women who risk their lives to serve our country and defend our freedom depend on Congress to ensure they have what they need to accomplish their missions.  One of the ways Congress does that is by passing the annual National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA).  An NDAA has been signed into law every year for the past 55 years.  Our committee passed next year’s bill out this past week by a vote of 60 to 1, and we expect to consider the bill on the House Floor next week.

I was glad to welcome this year’s Congressional Art Contest winner, Haley Garber of Caprock High School in Amarillo, to D.C. Haley and her mother, Suzanne, made the trip to Washington D.C. for the ceremony. I am impressed by the talent and dedication of this young student and am proud to have her artwork represent our part of Texas for the next year. You can read more about Haley, her artwork, and the art competition by visiting my website here: http://thornberry.house.gov/art/
Our sympathies and prayers go out to the families of those killed on the KC-130 crash in Mississippi last night. There must and will be a full investigation to determine the cause.
NA

Today, the House passed H.R. 2810, the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) for Fiscal Year 2018 with a vote of 344-81. For the 56th year in a row, the House has passed a bipartisan bill that prioritizes the men and women in uniform who selflessly volunteer to support and defend our nation.  This bill takes the necessary steps to begin to rebuild and reform our military, including billions in additional funds to begin to close the dangerous readiness gaps our troops are facing.
NA

The House passed and I voted for three bills to reform regulations and federal requirements affecting energy production and delivery – H.R. 806, “Ozone Standards Implementation Act of 2017,” H.R. 2910, “Promoting Interagency Coordination for Review of Natural Gas Pipelines Act,” and H.R. 2883, “Promoting Cross-Border Energy Infrastructure Act.”   There is no question that burdensome energy regulations and unnecessary bureaucratic delays drive up costs and waste time for businesses, which ultimately hurts consumers. These three bills are a step in the right direction to pull back some of the misguided regulations and decisions we have seen over the past few years.

My thoughts and prayers are with my friend, Senator John McCain.  He is, above all, a patriot.  I know that the courage and the remarkable spirit and tenacity that has marked his life will guide him in the challenges ahead.

Today, the House passed and I voted for H.R. 2825, “The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Authorization Act of 2017.” This is first reauthorization of the DHS since its creation after the 9/11 attacks.  Almost 16 years later, our country faces more serious and complex security challenges than ever before, and we must make sure Americans are protected.

This week, the House passed several bills to provide support to our veterans, including the “Harry W. Colmery Veterans Educational Assistance Act of 2017.”  This bill removes the time restrictions to use the GI Bill, letting future recipients use their GI benefits on their own time, when they need it most.   Meeting our commitments to our veterans is one of the most important responsibilities of the federal government.  These men and women have put their lives on the line to keep our country safe, and they deserve our best in return.
I am scheduled to be on Fox News this morning at 8:30 am Texas time to talk about sanctions, the situation in North Korea, and military funding and preparedness.
NA

I am extremely disappointed that the Senate has been unable to pass any version of a health care bill.  The House passed a bill to repeal and replace the worst parts of Obamacare in May, and the Senate should do the same.  Obamacare is simply not working as promised.  It will get worse.  We must continue to work to stop the harmful effects of this law, control costs, and put patients in charge of their health care.

Recently, I met with the Corn Producers Association to discuss the Farm Bill, tax reform, trade, and other issues that affect agricultural producers.  It is important that we continue to educate everyone about the hard work that goes into the production of the food we so easily buy at the grocery store.  A lot of that hard work comes from the people of our part of Texas.

After seven months of the 115th Congress, I want to provide a status report on where the major legislative issues stand.  While some in the media may be telling a different story, we have seen a lot of progress on many of the issues important to our area and to our country.  Click on the newsletter below for more information:

I was glad to visit with Lottie Urschel and her Ag teacher, Jennifer Warren, from Canyon, TX, who were here for the FFA Washington Leadership Conference.  I am proud to see bright, young people from our district promoting the well-being of agriculture and agricultural producers.

I was happy to meet pastors and church leaders from Temple of Praise Community Church in Amarillo during their visit to Washington, D.C.  It is always encouraging to meet people who are God's "hands and feet" in our community.

I enjoyed meeting with members of the Texas Farm Credit System while they were in Washington.  It is important for groups like these to continue to talk about the importance of our agricultural producers.

It was a pleasure to have Dr. Robert Riza, the President of Clarendon College, and his wife, Cobette Riza, visit us in Washington.  Clarendon College is playing a major role in educating the next generation, and I am impressed by the great work being done in my hometown.

Troop 89 from Amarillo visited Washington recently for the Boy Scout Jamboree.  I enjoyed talking to them about their experience in D.C. and the responsibilities of citizenship.  I am proud that such bright young men are representing District 13.

Sally and I are praying for the victims and their families of Hurricane Harvey, as well as for the rescuers.  As communities begin to take stock of everything that has been lost, Texans must stick together and help our neighbors.        Below is a link to the American Red Cross donation center:

“If you gave just a few minutes to the news, you saw it all—the generosity and courage, the sense of community, of people who really care about each other. You saw the pontoons and air mattresses and bass boats and rowboats and pool floats in which people were rescued. No one knows how many were saved or how many saved them.”

Today, the House passed, and I voted for, $7.85 billion in emergency funding for the immediate relief and recovery efforts for Hurricane Harvey.  This is the first step in addressing the critical needs for victims and communities affected by Harvey.    For the full bill text click the link below:

Disaster assistance should be considered on its own – not to advance another agenda.  I voted on Wednesday for a clean emergency disaster funding bill for Hurricane Harvey that passed the House with overwhelming support.  Those affected by disasters need help from Washington, they do not need more of the same political games.  For my full statement follow the link below:
Congress keeps holding military funding hostage. That’s a recipe for disaster.

Many of us will always remember where we were and what we were doing on September 11, 2001.  I was at a breakfast at the Pentagon when we heard about the first plane to hit the World Trade Center and left about 20 minutes before the plane hit the Pentagon itself.  Shortly thereafter, the Capitol complex was evacuated, and I was primarily concerned about making sure my family was safe.    16 years later, we still face terrorist threats and other dangers around the world.  But on this day, I remember the innocent victims of 9/11.  And I give thanks for the men and women in the Armed Forces, in the Intelligence Community, and in law enforcement who have worked and sacrificed to stop further terrorist attacks and to keep us safe.
NA
I encourage you to read this letter from Secretary of Defense Mattis that shows the damaging effects of yet another Continuing Resolution (CR) on our military.

U.S. Congressman Rick Larsen and I introduced “The Rural Veterans Travel Enhancement Act,” H.R. 3720, to assist veterans in rural areas get to and from their medical appointments.    One of the primary responsibilities of the federal government is to support the men and women who serve our country.  These men and women have put their lives on the line for our everyday freedoms.  We will never truly repay them for their sacrifices, but programs and legislation like this measure are important to better serve our veterans’ needs.
NA

I wanted to share an article describing some of our efforts in the House to make sure our nation is prepared to fight and win in space.  Our military and economy is so reliant on space, we cannot afford to fall behind our competitors in this domain.  This is a good, objective analysis of the issues surrounding our efforts.

Senator Cornyn and I continue to follow closely the Red River lawsuit and a potential settlement.  We are also working to advance our legislation that has passed the House and is pending in the Senate.  Private property rights are a foundational cornerstone of our economy and of our way of life, and it is important that we push to protect them in every way that we can.

To create jobs, grow the economy, and improve everyone’s standard of living, we need to let hard working taxpayers keep more of the money they earn.  We also need to simplify the tax code.  House and Senate Republicans and the Administration have jointly released a unified framework for tax reform.  We have a great opportunity to reform the tax code in a way that lowers taxes and fuels stronger economic growth while simplifying the burdens placed on ordinary taxpayers.  Both Congress and the President are committed to this goal.  Below is an overview of the tax reform framework.  For the full framework and more information visit here: https://fairandsimple.gop/   I encourage you to email me, send mail, or call my office to give feedback on this initial tax reform framework.

Our military will always need the best equipment, but our success on the battlefield starts with the people.  From the training that goes on at Sheppard AFB, to the recruitment efforts taking place in Amarillo, our communities should be proud of what we contribute to protecting our nation.

Our world is not getting any safer, and it is essential to support those, such as law enforcement and military, whose job it is to protect us.

Weekly tax update: Larger standard deduction    Our tax code is too complex, rewards special interests, and puts U.S. workers and businesses at a disadvantage when competing with those from other countries.  We can do better.    Under the framework for tax reform, the standard deduction would nearly double to $12,000 for single filers and $24,000 for married couples.  These changes simplify the tax filing system and create a larger “zero tax bracket” by eliminating taxes on the first large portion of money that you earn.       To see the full framework visit: www.fairandsimple.gop   As you may know, this is simply a framework for tax reform - suggestions and ideas are welcome.

Recently, I visited Nokona Glove in Nocona, Texas, to meet with Bobby Storey and his family.  They have been making ball gloves for 83 years and still going strong.  Bobby is a great example of the hardworking folks that we have in our part of Texas and a great reminder of who we are working for in Washington.
NA

Weekly Tax Update: Small businesses – pass-through rate  Hardworking small business owners are the foundation of our economy, and they have become some of most vulnerable under our current tax code.  Under the current law, pass-through businesses pay their taxes through their personal tax returns at individual rates, which can be as high as 39.6%.  The new framework limits the maximum tax rate for small and family-owned pass-through businesses to 25%, creating a fairer system for American workers and small businesses.    To see the full framework visit: www.fairandsimple.gop   As you may know, this is simply a framework for tax reform - suggestions and ideas are welcome.

For helpful information visit: https://www.dhs.gov/stopthinkconnect

Today, the House passed, and I voted for, H.R. 2142, the “INTERDICT Act,”  which provides Custom and Border Protection (CBP) with enhanced chemical screening devices and scientific support to detect and intercept fentanyl and other synthetic opioids.  Because most fentanyl that enters the U.S. originates in China or Mexico, it is important that we provide CBP with the tools they need to stop these dangerous substances from entering our country.

Saturday, Special Olympics athletes, West Texas A&M students, and Midwestern State students competed in the first Highway 287 Unified Bowl.  It was a great event for students and athletes from across our part of Texas.
I was on Fox News last night with Martha MacCallum to discuss the incident in Niger. To view the video click the link below:
NA

Weekly Tax Update: Lower rates for individuals and families  The current tax code is unfair and too complex.  Under current law, there are seven tax brackets for individuals and families.  The tax reform framework creates a fairer and simpler system by reducing it into three brackets – 12%, 25%, 35%.  As we continue to look at comprehensive tax reform, there may be an additional top rate for the highest-income taxpayers.  By lowering rates and simplifying the federal tax code, hard-working Americans will keep more of the money they earn and spend less time calculating their taxes.     To see the full framework visit: www.fairandsimple.gop  As you may know, this is simply a framework for tax reform – suggestions and ideas are welcome.

Today, the House introduced H.R. 1, the "Tax Cuts and Jobs Act."  This tax reform bill is about promoting a strong economy, simplifying the tax code, creating jobs, and letting hardworking Americans keep more of the money they earn.  It is time to bring jobs back to America and become more competitive in the world market.  The House, Senate, and the Administration have been dedicated to this goal.  It is time for tax reform.  82.6 percent of filers in Texas 13 claim the standard deduction - this bill doubles that.  Over 19 percent of filers in our district claim the Child Tax Credit - this bill increases that by $600 per child and allows more filers to claim this credit.  This bill will mean more money is left in the pockets of Texas taxpayers and will give a boost to our economy.  To read a section-by-section summary of H.R. 1 click the link below:
NA

I was pleased to travel to Israel to meet with Prime Minister Netanyahu and other officials about the importance of missile defense.  The threat from missile attacks continues to grow around the world, and our adversaries are rapidly advancing their technology.  It is important that the United States and our allies work together to stay ahead of the threat.

The country again witnessed incredible evil with the church shooting in Sutherland Springs, Texas.  As we pray for those affected by this tragedy, we are reminded to support and appreciate those who work every day to keep us safe.

The House Ways and Means Committee consideration of H.R. 1, the “Tax Cuts and Jobs Act,” is a significant step towards reforming our broken tax code.  This tax plan will help you keep more of the money you earn and will make the tax code fairer and simpler for everyone.  I encourage you to look at the details of the bill.  While further adjustments will be made, the Tax Foundation, a nonpartisan organization, ran the numbers and found that the bill would lower tax rates and the cost of capital, which would “lead to 3.9 percent higher GDP over the long term [and] 3.1 percent higher wages.” To see the full study click here: https://taxfoundation.org/tax-cuts-jobs-act-state-impact/  To see the full bill visit: https://waysandmeans.house.gov/taxreform/

Last week was the groundbreaking for the new Eisenhower Memorial in Washington to honor the former President and Allied Commander in World War II.  I have been a member of the Eisenhower Memorial Commission from its inception as the Texas representative since Eisenhower was born in Denison, Texas.  Memorials not only honor the past, they inspire us and lift us up to a higher plane as we face our own challenges.  This one will do that when it is completed on the anniversary of VE Day in 2020.

It is also a chance to recognize the families of veterans, who also serve our nation.  Sally and I thank our veterans and our servicemembers, not only today, but every day. The U.S. House of Representatives passed the conference report of the Fiscal Year 2018 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) by a vote of 356 to 70.  The conference report will now be approved by the Senate and sent to the President for signature.  Over the last several years, we have seen an increase in threats and a decrease in funding for our military.  This year's NDAA begins to rebuild our military and to ensure we can defend the American people.  It also supports our troops.  Our servicemembers volunteer to risk their lives to protect us and our freedom.  We owe them the best that our country can provide -  the best equipment, in the best shape, with the best training.

Today, I voted in support of H.R.1, the "Tax Cuts and Jobs Act," which passed the House by a vote of 227-205.  It is time to create jobs, grow the economy, and improve everyone’s standard of living.  We need to let hard working taxpayers keep more of the money they earn - that is exactly what this bill does.  This tax reform is our chance to lower taxes, simplify the tax code, and give our economy the boost it needs.

Did you know that the H.R. 1, the “Tax Cuts and Jobs Act,” that passed the House, allows all Americans to continue using popular retirement savings options – like 401(k)s and Individual Retirement Accounts (IRAs) – to plan and save for the future?
NA

Sally and I wish all of you a Happy Thanksgiving.  We all have so much to be thankful for in this great country, and the holidays serve as a reminder of these blessings.  Today, as we gather with family and friends, I hope we all give thanks to the men and women who are serving our country across the world to keep us safe.

Did you know that the H.R. 1, the “Tax Cuts and Jobs Act,” that passed the House, benefits family-owned farming and ranching businesses by immediately doubling the death tax exemption and fully repealing it after seven years?  Death should never be a taxable event.
NA

Yesterday, the House passed H.R. 2228, the “Law Enforcement Mental Health and Wellness Act of 2017,” which directs the Department of Justice to study and report on best practices and services of the Department of Defense and Department of Veterans Affairs that could be adopted by law enforcement agencies.  We have learned a lot over the past several years, and those who protect our safety every day should benefit from it.

The Speaker of the House signed the Fiscal Year 2018 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA).  While threats around the world have gotten more numerous and more complex, our military budget has been cut.  This year’s NDAA begins to rebuild and repair our military and gives our troops the largest pay increase in eight years.   Our servicemembers risk their lives every day to protect our freedoms and our safety, and for that, we owe them the support they deserve.
NA

Today, the House passed and I cosponsored H.R. 38, the "Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act of 2017."  The Second Amendment to the Constitution establishes a citizen's right to keep and bear arms, yet it is constantly being attacked.  The ‘Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act of 2017,’ helps protect those rights.  Just like we expect one state to respect a driver’s license from another state, we should expect one state to recognize another’s concealed carry permit.  To read the fill bill visit: http://docs.house.gov/billsthisweek/20171204/BILLS-115HR38-RCP115-45.pdf

Today, is the 76th anniversary of Pearl Harbor.  It is a day to honor the service and sacrifice of our men and women in uniform who risk their lives for our freedom and security.  It is also a reminder of the dangers of being unprepared and the importance of a strong and ready military.

Communicating with people from the 13th district is an essential part of my job and something I take seriously.  Because communicating is so important, I have updated my website to make it easier to navigate and easier to understand.  The new website will also use less data to access and is mobile friendly.  All of these qualities make it easier for me to communicate with the people I work for.  I invite you to check out the new website and let me know what you think: https://thornberry.house.gov/

This week, the House passed H.R. 3971, the “Community Institution Mortgage Relief Act of 2017,”  which will exempt certain small and mid-size lenders from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) rule that requires lenders to establish escrow accounts for mortgage borrowers.     This is another step toward rolling back some of the burdensome, Obama-era regulations under the Dodd-Frank Act.
NA

Last week, I launched my new website to make communicating with the people of District 13 easier.  I invite you to fill out the survey below to let me know what issues are most important to you and your family.

Key facts about the tax reform bill on its way to the President:  1) According to the Tax Policy Center, 44% of Americans do not pay any federal individual income tax.  It should be no surprise that most of the income tax relief goes to the 56% who actually pay income taxes.    2) The median income for a family of four today is $73,000.  That family will pay $2,059 less in federal income tax under this bill according to the House and Senate tax committees.  3) 82.6% of the people who file tax returns in the 13th District of Texas do not itemize deductions and use the standard deduction.  That standard deduction increases from $6,350 for an individual to $12,000, nearly double, and is indexed for inflation in the future.  4) The average corporate tax rate in Europe is about 18%.  The 21% corporate rate in this bill is a big reduction but still higher than some of our key competitors.   5) This bill repeals the individual mandate in Obamacare starting January 1, 2019.   To read more about the tax reform bill, please visit https://waysandmeans.house.gov/taxreform/.

Today, the House passed a disaster relief bill.  Relief for those in Texas and other states dealing with the devastation of the recent natural disasters is needed and welcomed.  This emergency funding will continue the efforts to recover, rebuild, and reduce the impact of future natural disasters.  This bill also provides permanent relief to all cotton producers, including those affected by the disasters, by making seed cotton eligible for the farm safety net that is on par with the support provided to other crops.  Additionally, it lifts the cap on the Livestock Gross Margin insurance program to ensure that livestock producers, including dairy farmers, have adequate risk management tools available during disasters.

Sally and I would like to wish you and your family a merry and blessed Christmas.  It is easy to become consumed with the conflicts of our country and our world, but this time of year is an opportunity to step back and remember that the burden is not just upon us.  God sent us a savior to take our future into His hands.    Isaiah 9:6 says, “For a child will be born to us, a son will be given to us; And the government will rest on His shoulders.”
Congratulations to the Muenster Hornets football team for winning the Class 2A Division II state championship last week.

U.S. Rep. Mac Thornberry's office will host a service academy forum in Amarillo on Saturday, April 1, 2017 from 9:00 a.m. until 11:00 a.m. for individuals interested in attending a U.S military service academy. The event will be held at the Texas Air and Space Museum at Rick Husband Amarillo International Airport.  The forum is open to all young men and women interested in attending one of the U.S. Service Academies and their parents. Information will also be available regarding university level ROTC.  The Nomination Process:  To be considered for an appointment to a service academy, an applicant must meet the eligibility requirements established by law and be nominated from an authorized person including a Member of the United States Senate or the House of Representatives. I may nominate applicants who are legally domiciled within the boundaries of our district.  Who Is Eligible?  An applicant for a nomination must meet the following eligibility requirements as of July 1 of the year of admission to a service academy. He or she must be at least 17 years old, but not have passed the 23rd birthday, must be a United States citizen, and must be unmarried, not pregnant, and have no legal obligation to support children or other dependents.  Applying To My Office For A Nomination:  Students interested in a nomination should complete an academy appointment application in the spring of their junior year in high school. You may fax the completed application to (806) 371-7044 or mail it to my Amarillo office (905 South Fillmore Street, Suite 520, Amarillo, TX 79101). Also, please note that it is extremely important that the student begin the application process with the academies themselves.   Service Academies  There are five Service Academies: The United States Air Force (USAFA), Naval (USNA), Military (USMA), Merchant Marine (USMMA), and Coast Guard (USCGA) Academies. Nominations are required for all but the U.S. Coast Guard Academy, to which appointments are made on the basis of an annual nationwide competition.  As far as the USAFA, USNA, and USMA are concerned, there are various nomination authorities, with each eligible young person being able to apply to both United States Senators from the applicant's state, his or her United States Representative, and the Vice President (if very highly qualified). The other nomination categories are military-affiliated.  With respect to the Congressional category, each Representative and each Senator is allowed to have at each of those academies at any one time five persons charged to his or her quota. There are three methods of nominating, and I use the competitive method. For each vacancy, ten nominations may be made on a strictly competitive basis. The competitive method provides that the nominees compete among themselves for final appointment determined by the admissions authorities. They take into consideration a nominee's academic record, extracurricular and athletic activities, physical aptitude, ACT and/or SAT scores, leadership ability, and medical qualifications. Such facets of an applicant's record are also considered during the nomination selection process. No person will be offered admission if he or she does not meet the physical standards of the Academy unless awarded a medical waiver.  As competition for nomination and appointment is very keen, it is wise for all interested persons to apply through all sources for which they are eligible and for all Academies in which they have a real interest. An individual may be nominated by more than one nominating authority and/or to more than one Academy.  With regard to the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy, the locality boundary for nomination by a Representative is the State in which the District lies rather than just the District itself. Each Representative and each Senator may nominate ten candidates each year to compete for admission.   Learn more about Service Academy Nominations, and pick up your application today, by visiting my website.  http://thornberry.house.gov/ConstituentServices/ServiceAcademyNominations.htm  Photo courtesy of the United States Military Academy Media Relations.

Nominations are required for all but the U.S. Coast Guard Academy, to which appointments are made on the basis of an annual nationwide competition.  As far as the USAFA, USNA, and USMA are concerned, there are various nomination authorities, with each eligible young person being able to apply to both United States Senators from the applicant's state, his or her United States Representative, and the Vice President (if very highly qualified). The other nomination categories are military-affiliated.  With respect to the Congressional category, each Representative and each Senator is allowed to have at each of those academies at any one time five persons charged to his or her quota. There are three methods of nominating, and I use the competitive method. For each vacancy, ten nominations may be made on a strictly competitive basis. The competitive method provides that the nominees compete among themselves for final appointment determined by the admissions authorities. They take into consideration a nominee's academic record, extracurricular and athletic activities, physical aptitude, ACT and/or SAT scores, leadership ability, and medical qualifications. Such facets of an applicant's record are also considered during the nomination selection process. No person will be offered admission if he or she does not meet the physical standards of the Academy unless awarded a medical waiver.  As competition for nomination and appointment is very keen, it is wise for all interested persons to apply through all sources for which they are eligible and for all Academies in which they have a real interest. An individual may be nominated by more than one nominating authority and/or to more than one Academy.  With regard to the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy, the locality boundary for nomination by a Representative is the State in which the District lies rather than just the District itself. Each Representative and each Senator may nominate ten candidates each year to compete for admission.   Learn more about Service Academy Nominations, and pick up your application today, by visiting my website.  http://thornberry.house.gov/ConstituentServices/ServiceAcademyNominations.htm  Photo courtesy of the United States Naval Academy Media Relations.
